reviewText:
TLDR; Cool concept, for a pretty niche community. Unfortnately there's no singleplayer mode and finding other players can take upwards of 10 minutes. Controls can feel unresponsive, but gameplay is genuinely fun. Online community feels dead and the game lacks varitey and customisability.

I imagine they'd also be rolling out more updates in the future for more content, as it is there are 6 tracks and 6 different cars. When you start out you have no cars theres 6 to pick from and you have a choice of the first two as they are under 200K which is what you're given when you start out. The car models do look pretty good and was impressed with the details they were able to put into the models. After buying the car you want, take it to your garage and with whatever spare cash you have left you might be able to get an upgrade. The upgradeable aspects of your car are the brake, ECU, Exhaust, bodywork, suspension, KERS, spoiler, cooling and a few others. Upgrades will change the car in terms of fuel economy, top speed, accleration, drag, braking power and do matter. For instance the car I was using was kitted to last only about 25km's without pitting but I had constantly more power to use and ended out on top. Most races won't be longer than 50km's, also note drivers can be more fuel economic whilst driving.

Once you're actually in-game it's pretty fun, you instruct your AI driver around and tell him when to use KERS, push harder, when to change the car's fuel map, pitstops and block. Controls can feel like they are unresponsive at times but that's due to driver stats which can be upgrades with experience points.

Experience points can be used to increase the speed of certain aspects of your pitstop, increase the skill of your driver; how confident he is with braking and overtaking and how much speed he can carry through corners. You also have a manager who handles all your sponsorship contracts, you can give him greater chance of securing a contract and he can land better contracts for you aswell.

Contracts themselves aren't overly fun to handle. You're given 10 time units and every action uses a certain amount of time units, time units are replentished after each race. Pretty easy mechanic but monotonous is a good way to describe sponsorship (10/10 immersion there). To actually land a deal you need to call up the sponsor which you might or might not get through to. Once you're in you can invite them out to dinner, send them gifts, give a presentation on your raceteam few other options I've forgotten. Each option will better the relationship between you and whomever you're chasing up.

Once a you manage to squeeze out a contract offer you can change the aspects of the contract, how much you get paid, for how many races and what position you need to come in to adhere to those conditions of receiving the funds.

All up I would recommend this game if they added more varitey and the online community was bigger, it's a fairly niche market so this game may never live up to it's full potential. In it's current state I wouldn't recommend this game.

Apologies for the length of the review, it all got a bit out of hand. Cheers.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In this game you become the manager of your own racing team. You won't find here popular car brands like Ferrari or Maserati but just a fictional racing cars.

Overview
As a team manager you can sign new sponsor offers and help the driver to drive around the track. By earning money out of every race you can then upgrade the car or buy a new color design. The racing itself is from 3rd person perspective so you see a very small cars. As a team manager you can instruct the driver to: overtake, overload, block or tail the following car. The second set of options is: KERS button, changing the engine's ECU fuel mapping or requesting the driver to make a pitstop. Instructing the driver to overtake the following car can be from the left or right side and it works pretty well but sometimes the AI fails causing strange situations. The rest of the options work pretty well.

Game modes
Single race or cup mode - new in the game. In the cup mode you also have qualification lap which i felt lacking before. Cup mode provides you also some more fun because of strategy, because there are 3 races that are longer and therefore you can go on one pitstop or two.

Balance
The game is all the time on the same level. When you start there are many cars faster than you and some of them are slower. It means that after you do the upgrades to the car your car becomes more competetive and heads to the front of the opponents. After you upgrade your car to the maximum you fight for the first places. It means that after you do it your car is always in the front so if you don't have real players as the opponents, you almost always fight for win. There should be some racing categories or one type of car races to make it more interesting.

Multiplayer
It's the first issue - because the game doesn't have singleplayer, the game is always looking for online players. Sadly almost all the time you compete with the bots and maybe 1-2 real players.

Graphics & audio
Everything looks very nice, has good sounds. The music becomes a little boring after 5 or 10 races but you can turn it off. Some optimalizations must be made to the game because of the high cpu/gpu usage, but so far it works nice.

Summary
There are still some bugs like for example disapearing wheels, lapped cars still fight like they were racing while they shouldn't. The game needs some work but the direction is so far very good and i can recommend this game. If you like racing games, you'll definetely like this one!

reviewText:
PLAY THIS GAME IF YOU LOVE MOTORSPORT AND CIRCUIT RACING

This game uniquely explores how important it is to properly manage tyres and fuel for pitstops as well as the importance of playing the strengths of cars to their fullest, you must determine when and where to push the car to its limits and when to drive it more economically. You'll be constantly doing math to figure out if you're under or exceeding your fuel quota and you will also be watching the tyre wear so you don't burn them out too fast and make the wear eat into your lap times.

To add to the mix you can monitor what actions and strategies the opponents are employing throughout the race, this will sometimes make you rethink your strategy - will you let him pass and tail him or will you run your car at 100% and try to outrun him and if so, for how long? Keep in mind that running the car at full throttle eats into fuel and you'll finish most races with 0% - 5% fuel remaining so choose wisely.

The tuning aspect of the game allows you to buy newer and better parts, some more suited for speed and power while others are suited better for handling and fuel economy, the challenge is to build a car that is well adapted for most situations and having strengths that can be used to secure wins. Your team can be upgraded too which consists of a Driver, the Pit Crew and lastly your Marketing Manager who is in charge of obtaining sponsorship deals.

The game is still early in development phase and has numerous errors or design faults but it still brings a lot to the table, races are randomly selected and sometimes you will be put into a race where your cars setup has almost no chance of placing within the top 5 not even looking at first, this will be ironed out down the line but can detract from the experience. Pitstop bugs have happened before as well and I've had a few bugs with tyre selection costing me races in the past but I'm willing to overlook them for the time being while the developer fixes then; the developer is very active and open with progress on the steam forums so help is never too far away.

And lastly a piece of advice for the people who are considering or have just bought the game and have yet to choose a car: buy the Raptor if you want an easier experience, buy the Avalanche if you want to grind your face into the wall but learn a lot more about strategy and have a greater challenge on the managing side of things. This game is ideal for those who know a lot about racecraft but are looking to expand their knowledge on race strategy.

reviewText:
I bought this game thinking it would be the GTR equivalent of a football managing title. I was surprised to find that, although related to the managing genre in the various tasks you attend to when not actually racing, this is actually a deeply rewarding real-time pvp strategy game.

This is how it works. Up to 16 players compete in races where you control the various strategic and tactical tasks that go towards running a racing team. Pitstop and tyre strategy is, of course, key to your success and winning a race on the last lap because of your fresh tyres is a thing of pure joy. But there's more still - you actually control a lot of your drivers actions. Engine mapping, KERs deployment, deliberately tail-gating to save fuel, whether you want your driver to attempt an overtake (and which side to try it on) or whether to drive defensively - all these things you control in real-time.

However the real gem here is the multiplayer element. I've owned this less than a day and already I have had some amazing duels with budding team managers from all over the world. The community is fresh and happy with the game right now, which is always nice to be a part of.

Don't get me wrong, this is clearly a rather niche title as well as an independent one (so not without it's annoying quirks or balancing issues) but for someone who spends every Sunday glued to the telly screaming at Ron Dennis that I could do his job so much better this is absolutely perfect and I love it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is unique, and fun to play when it works. Online stability is pretty iffy, and there isn't a whole lot of content just yet. I’d be interested to follow up with the game over time to see how it’s shaping up, as the devs have been dropping patches frequently. If they can manage to eliminate most of the server issues and add a bit of content, this game has the potential to become genuinely special.

It’s worth mentioning that the game is being developed by a small studio of six people, and it already looks fantastic. The in-race lighting effects, especially during nighttime runs, are impressive, especially among its Early Access peers. Taking into consideration that cooperative racing teams are in the works as well, allowing for you and your friends to take on races together in your sponsor-covered customized cars, Trackday Manager might be one of the most compelling racing experiences to grace PC gaming in a long while. Easy to learn, but bloody difficult to master, this is definitely one to watch.

This game ticks many boxes for me.  It's like a collaboration of a few games I've played over the years.

I began my interest inside arcades around the late 70s/early 80s.  There was a mechanical racing game -- in which you put in 2pence or 10pence (memory!), and the mechanical cars zoomed around a scaletrix-like track -- the cars were colour coded -- and if the car you bet upon was on the finish line -- you won some moolah!  Well, it wasn't moolah -- but it felt like it at the time!  I loved it.

Flash-forward, and this game also reminds me of super sprint.  Another arcade release, which this time got ported over to various computers of the day.  I was a spectrum guy, but I liked my friends C64 version better.

Flash-forward quite a few years later -- this game also reminds me WRC Powerslide.  I played this on XBOX360,  of which I've been a gamer, or rather, a racer for quite some time.   I really enjoy rally, and this different perspective was fab.

Onward we go, and deciding upon an XBox One or PC Gaming has been a tough choice.

I went for change.

Trackday Manager is my first game on steam -- and I'm super-impressed.  Although, it must be said -- it was probably an easy sell given my history.

The game is under early-access, but I don't have any perspective of this -- so I'm just giving the game a battering and not trying to be overly critical of any bugs and such.  On the flip-side to Steam in-maturity stands a laid-back, it will get done when its done kind of guy.  But let's work towards getting it done in an efficient manner.

I'm sure there's things cropping up which the developers didn't think about, didn't consider, didn't think were possible -- but then -- this is why they are developers -- development takes time.

The game can be simple.  The game can be intricate.  Track position can be king.  Strategy can rule.  The possiibilities are endless.

My name is razzitGT.

I'll see you on the track.

reviewText:
I thought it was time to update my EA review which was positive but also had a lot of fixes and recommendations. A year or so on, I feel I am at the same stage where the game has now been released and it's as enjoyable as ever but you get the feeling it left EA a month or two earlier than it should have.

Overall the game is a great game and has that one more go appeal. I won't go into the specifics of what the game is about as there are many other reviews covering that aspect. I guess some of my thoughts may have been covered on the forum already, but I haven't read through each comment, so bear with me if I have said the obvious which has been covered.

Pros:
- I can't think of any other game like this on Steam
- Great racing and your strategy can really make a difference.
- Nice weather affects which really do change a game mid race.
- Graphics are ideal for this type of game
- Developers all be it small are in constant comms with the players and seem a dedicated bunch who have a proper passion for the game
- The AI could be better but not bad either.
- Able to play when there are not enough people online
- Good community so far, bar the odd disconnector which I gather has now been patched
- If you're a stoner, it's an ideal sit back and veg type game, with tiny mouse inputs throughout :)
- Other race modes look great, but no dates on when they will be ready

Cons
- Matchmaking leaves a lot to be desired. New players are already faced with meeting the 'new' cars and the issue becomes worse if you meet someone with a flying time as the AI will then also follow the fastest persons time, thus making it nigh on impossible to get anywhere.

I understand the concern of matchmaking would make less people per race at this present time, but racing against bots your own level would help their progression for new players.
- Lag, but I'm not sure if it's just me but it seems to be getting better?
- Certain tracks suit certain cars. Not being able to make at least a change or two at the lobby stage to suit the track does hinder your chances.
- Oval track (Sorry I hate this track)
- Other car modes and cup features not being ready on launch.
- Some bugs from EA are still here a year on.


Recommendations
- I know there are 2 sides to this one, but reverse grids in Quick Race as well as Cup to try to balance the game out. otherwise we're going to keep losing new players to refund which I have discussed on a previous post.
- You should have the option when being slipstreamed to shake the car off rather than just have him tail you to save fuel and there is nothing you can do bar pit.
- Reverse tracks to vary the races
- More tracks and to balance out the tracks for speed and also handling of the cars
- Make race distances varied with Sprint, normal and enduro distances.
- Sort out the matchmaking
- Try to introduce another compound for a tyre, medium? This will again add more strategy to the game. For me the game is more enjoyable from a strategic point of view than the actual racing.
- Giving the player the option to make 1 or 2 changes max when you find out what track your on in the lobby would help things as there is nothing worse than having a handling set up to then find out you are on the oval. Obviously works the same way vica versa.
- It needs more upgradeable parts to vary things.

Overall I still stand by and give the game a positive review. I've been here since day one and have seen it when we had no servers for days and bugs that made the game totally unplayable.

What we have now isn't perfect by any means and there is a long way to go, but give the devs a chance as this game could be a great game if we keep the number of players up and it ever improves.

Anyway, that's my tuppence.

I've been looking for this style of game.  You are not the driver.  You're the Crew Chief and Spotter for your Driver.  You give your Driver commands such as overtake either left or right, draft, block a car behind, or pit.  This is the stragety.  What tires for what weather or track.  How much gas to add.  All of your team can raise thier skills.  Your Driver can raise different skills to better his abilities as well as your entire Pit Crew and your Marketing.

Early Access Review

Please buy this game. Its not perfect but I get the impression a successful launch and focused devs could make this an amazing game.

I'm addicted but and its a BIG BUT the development of this game will have to focus on real gameplay for me to stay addicted. Too many of these management games dedicate time, effort and ultimately my computer memory to periferal things that in truth are needless niceties. The Sponsorship element fits this category and whilst I wouldn't remove it I think the development should focus on a more balanced list of competing cars (I read someone else commenting on this), more in play commands (the current ones are good and pretty satisfying), a set up module and a practice mode which allows you to gain more understanding over the effects of things like tire wear and ECU settings.

I would also suggest the option of longer races (obviously not 24 hour but maybe double the roughly 10 minute current run).

Finally I would just point out a lot of the in game play is a process of trial and error as there isn't much in the way of detailed guides or instructions. I quite like this but thats why with this ommission a practice option is pretty much essential.
